Award.AwardTitle: Photoion and Photoelectron Spectroscopy of Metal Clusters and Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Dong-Sheng Yang of the University of Kentucky and his research group will investigate the bonding and structures of reactive gaseous metal clusters and metal-molecule complexes. Emphasis will be placed on early transition metal cluster oxides, which are relevant to catalysis, and lanthanide-benzene complexes, which are relevant to organometallic synthesis and also pose a challenge to quantum theories of chemical bonding. These short-lived chemical species will be prepared in laser-vaporization molecular beams, identified with photoionization mass spectrometry, and studied using a variety of techniques including zero electron kinetic energy photoelectron, mass analyzed threshold ionization, and infrared-ultraviolet photoionization spectroscopy. Combining the spectroscopic data and theoretical predictions will allow for the characterization of electronic states and molecular structures.

This research project will lead to new knowledge about the size-dependent structures and electronic properties of the metal clusters and metal-ligand binding and energetics of the metal complexes. The results will be of interest to practitioners in organometallic chemistry, surface sciences, materials synthesis, and chemical catalysis. This project provides technologically challenging research training opportunities for students and postdoctoral associates to prepare them effectively for careers in industry or academia.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

 

During this grant period, we published 20 peer-reviewed papers in well-read chemistry or chemical physics journals, presented 27 papers in regional, national, or international professional conferences, and completed three high-quality Ph.D. dissertations.

 

This project examined the bonding and structures of gas-phase metal clusters and complexes.  The metal complexes and clusters were produced in a molecular beam reactor, identified by time-of-flight mass spectrometry, and studied for the first time by high-resolution electron and ion spectroscopy. The key outcomes are the accurate ionization energies, metal-ligand and ligand-based vibrational frequencies, electronic states, and molecular structures of these chemically reactive species. The ionization energy is a basic thermochemical property of a molecule and is used to obtain the metal-ligand bond energy of the neutral molecule through a thermodynamic relation. The metal-ligand vibrational frequencies give direct evidence about the metal-ligand bonding, whereas the ligand-based vibrational frequencies probe the geometry of the metal-activated hydrocarbon fragments. The degree of the charge effect reveals the nature of the electron bonding in the highest molecular orbital. The knowledge about the bonding, structures, and electronic states of these chemically reactive specie gives new insight into the dynamics and mechanisms of metal reactions with aromatic hydrocarbons and oxygen molecules.

 

 

Broad Impact:

 

The project provides technically challenging training for students and prepared them effectively for careers in industry or academia. Seven graduate students and four postdoctoral fellows participated in the project at different times. The students gained experience in sophisticated instrumentation, advanced spectroscopic and imaging techniques, and modern computational chemistry. They learned skills in the design, operation, and interpretation of scientific experiments and in the presentation of research discoveries. The students gave at least one talk each year at the annual Ohio State University International Symposium on Molecular Spectroscopy or at American Chemical Society meetings, in addition to the research updates at regular group meetings and departmental seminar series. They wrote the manuscripts for the papers they were the first authors.  The principal investigator (PI) worked closely with the students in manuscript and seminar preparations.  It has been a very satisfying experience to observe the continuous improvement in their oral and writing skills.  The PI’s research group consists of students of both genders with diverse cultural backgrounds and has ongoing national and international collaborations. This environment further enriches student experience for future employment. The students from the PI’s group have gone on to successful positions in technical or educational workforce.

 

The new knowledge created from this work contributes to the advancement of organometallic chemistry, materials synthesis and chemical catalysis and to the undergraduate education. The spectroscopic data provides high standards to test computational models and helps the development of improved computational methods.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2014
Modified by: Dong-Sheng Yang
